metadata.case_name: Kakumanu Ramanna (minor, deceased) through legal representatives v. Kakumanu (first defendant) and Ors.

facts.text: Suit for partition of joint family properties instituted on April 2, 1942, in Court of District Munsif, Ongole, on behalf of minor Kakumanu Ramanna (age about 2 1/2 years) by his maternal grandfather Rangayya as next friend.

First defendant is father of plaintiff; second and third defendants are sons of first defendant by his deceased first wife; fourth defendant is second wife of first defendant and mother of plaintiff; fifth defendant is daughter of first defendant by fourth defendant.

Plaint alleged: (1) ill-treatment and neglect to maintain mother and children (not established by District Munsif and Subordinate Judge); (2) sale of family properties to Akkul Venkatasubba Reddi for Rs. 2,300 on May 9, 1939, without necessity, to injure plaintiff; (3) items 2 and 11 purchased on June 1, 1938, and June 14, 1939, with joint family funds but taken in names of second and third defendants to diminish assets.
Plaint stated family in good circumstances with no debts.
Defendants' written statements filed June 20, 1942: purchases of items 2 and 11 with separate funds of second and third defendants; joint family had debts of Rs. 2,600.
Minor plaintiff born on December 20, 1939; died in January 1943; his mother (fourth defendant) recorded as legal representative and transposed as second plaintiff.

District Munsif at rehearing: sale and purchases anterior to birth of plaintiff; no cause of action; items 2 and 11 belong to joint family (not proved separate funds); no debts; but no cause of action for partition; suit dismissed on December 23, 1946.
Subordinate Judge, Bapatla, affirmed findings on items 2/11 and no debts; agreed no cause of action as transactions prior to birth; dismissed appeal on January 28, 1949.
Madras High Court (Satyanarayana Rao J.): defendants falsely claimed items 2/11 as separate; adverse interest; suit beneficial to minor; preliminary decree for partition on April 10, 1953.
Defendants 1-3 in written statements denied title to items 2 and 11; adduced evidence at trial; persisted in appeal; courts below held against them concurrently.
First defendant admitted knowledge of pregnancy in May/June 1939 when transactions concluded.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit for partition was instituted for the benefit of the minor plaintiff, given that lower courts found no cause of action as transactions preceded his birth.

Whether a suit for partition instituted on behalf of a minor coparcener effects severance in status from the date of suit (conditional on court finding it beneficial), or only upon court's decree; and whether such suit abates on minor's death before adjudication of benefit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Concurrent finding by courts below that suit not instituted for benefit of minor; High Court had no power to reverse in second appeal as pure question of fact.

Suit abates on death of minor before court decides benefit; minor incapable of volition; division in status only when court exercises volition on his behalf; interest survives to coparceners, not heirs.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mitakshara law; Chelimi Chetty v. Subbamma; Lalta Prasad v. Sri Mahadeoji Birajman Temple; Hari Singh v. Pritam Singh

respondent_arguments.text: Defendants acted adversely by denying minor's title to items 2/11 and claiming debts; suit beneficial.
Suit by minor stands on same footing as adult coparcener; severance from date of suit conditional on court holding beneficial; does not abate on minor's death; legal representatives can continue.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Girja Bai v. Sadashiv Dhundiraj; Rangasayi v. Nagarathnamma; Ramsing v. Fakira; Mandliprasad v. Ramcharanlal

court_reasoning.text: Lower courts misdirected: transactions show adverse conduct post-birth (denial of title in WS while minor alive); beneficial to partition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defendants combined to deny title to items 2/11; persisted despite concurrent findings against; interest of minor to separate.

court_reasoning.text: Under Mitakshara, coparcener (including minor) has right to partition on birth; suit by next friend effects severance from institution date, conditional on court finding beneficial; court recognizes, does not create right.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Next friend expresses intention; court checks benefit as parens patriae; partition outside court by relation valid if beneficial.

court_reasoning.text: Overrules Chelimi Chetty etc.: power not exclusively court's; next friend can act, subject to approval; suit does not abate; actio personalis inapplicable as property suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Rangasayi, Ramsing, Mandliprasad; Girja Bai applies to minors via next friend.

holdings.text: Suit instituted for benefit of minor; High Court could interfere due to misdirection by lower courts.

Suit for partition by minor via next friend effects severance in status from date of plaint if court finds beneficial; does not abate on minor's death; legal representatives can continue and prove benefit.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held suit abates on minor's death; erroneous as court does not create severance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lalta Prasad v. Sri Mahadeoji Birajman Temple
precedents_cited.relevance: No alteration of status by minor's suit; followed Chelimi but overruled.
Severance only on decree date; followed Chelimi.
Severance from suit date conditional on benefit; suit continues post-death.
Suit does not abate; severance relates back.
Unequivocal intention (suit) effects severance; applies to minors via next friend.
Dismissal does not affect severance from suit date.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balkishen Das v. Ram Narain Sahu
precedents_cited.relevance: Partition by relation binding if beneficial.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal by special leave granted by Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Mitakshara Law (Hindu Law)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs coparcenary rights, partition, minor's entitlement from birth.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld Madras High Court's preliminary decree for partition, accepted that suit was for minor's benefit, and held that such suit effects severance from institution date (if beneficial) and does not abate on minor's death.

key_quotes.text: "the filing of a suit for partition is a clear expression of such an intention, and that, in consequence, there is a severance in status when the action for partition is filed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Citing Girja Bai; applies to minor suits via next friend.

key_quotes.text: "when a court decides that a suit for partition is beneficial to the minor, it does not itself bring about a division in status. The court is not in the position of a super-guardian."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "in all such cases the severance is effected from the date of the suit conditional on the court being able to find that the suit when filed was for the benefit of the minor."
key_quotes.speaker: court
